sentence: The world's largest home improvement retailer, The Home Depot Inc. ( HD ) delivered yet another better-than-expected quarterly result.

The company's earnings of 50 cents per share for fourth quarter fiscal 2011 climbed nearly 39% from the prior-period earnings of 36 cents, primarily driven by solid comparable sales growth and strong operating performance.
Quarterly earnings also surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 42 cents per share.
Moreover, the quarterly results were amplified by the increased number of centralized distribution centers and better merchandising tools.
Further, a mild winter season forced the spring demand to come forward, benefiting the quarter's performance.
For fiscal 2011, Home Depot's earnings of $2.47 per share handily surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.39 and surged approximately 23% from fiscal 2010.
A rise in comparable sales mainly contributed toward the growth.
During the reported quarter, net sales moved up 5.9% to $16,014 million compared with $15,126 million in the prior-year quarter, ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $15,505 million.
The increase in net sales resulted from a growth of 5.7% in overall comparable store sales.
Comparable store sales in U.S. stores rose 6.1% during the fourth quarter.
Net sales in fiscal 2011 grew 3.5% from the previous fiscal to $70,395 million, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $69,896 million.
During 2011, overall comparable store sales increased 3.4%, while comparable store sales in U.S. increased 3% from last year.
During the quarter, gross profit increased 6.8% to $5,597 million from $5,243 million reported in the prior-year quarter.
Consequently, gross profit margin expanded by 30 basis points (bps) to 35%.
Operating profit during the quarter increased robustly by 28.3% to $1,330 million compared with $1,037 million in the year-ago period.
Operating margin expanded 140 bps to 8.3% compared with 6.9% in the prior-year quarter.
Improvement in operating margin was primarily driven by improved gross profit margin and effective cost management.
Home Depot ended its fiscal 2011 with cash and cash equivalents of $1,987 million and long-term debt of $10,758 million.

During 2011, the company generated $6,651 million of cash from operations and deployed $3,470 million toward share buyback, $1,632 million for dividend payment, $1,028 million for debt repayment and $1,221 million as capital expenditures.
Following the better-than-expected fourth-quarter results, management anticipates the 2012 diluted earnings per share to increase 13% year on year to $2.79 (after share repurchases).
Moreover, management is expecting a growth of 4% in total sales during fiscal 2012 on the back of low-single-digit comparable store sales growth.
Gross margin is expected to expand moderately, while operating margin may see an expansion of 50 bps.
The company is planning for a capital expenditure of approximately $1,325 million and anticipates generating a free cash flow of $6,600 million.
Further, the company is also planning to open 11 new stores and repurchase nearly $3,500 million of its common stock.
Home Depot is a leading player in the highly-fragmented home improvement industry.
The company has reinvigorated itself with a shift in focus from new square footage growth to maximization of productivity through its existing store base.
In addition, the company has implemented significant changes to its store operations to make them simpler and more customer-friendly.
We believe these initiatives will induce more customer traffic to its stores, which will boost its top line.
Moreover, with the introduction of new warehousing and transportation system, the company has been able to improve its supply chain while minimizing the cost.
This has also helped Home Depot to improve its Central Automated Replenishment System to facilitate immediate refilling of stock while reducing the investment in inventory.
However, the company's business is highly competitive, primarily based on customer services, price, store location and assortment of merchandise.
The company faces stiff competition from local, regional and international players.
To maintain its market share, the company is making selective acquisitions and strategic alliances with third parties, which are increasing its operational risks.
Home Depot, which competes with Lowe's Companies Inc. ( LOW ) currently, has a Zacks #3 Rank, implying a short-term 'Hold' rating.
Besides, the company retains a long-term 'Neutral' recommendation.
